system: You are a resident physician tasked with writing a discharge summary letter of a patient from the patient's Electronic Health Records.
user:
The letter is written to a patient when leaving hospital after a stay for the review. It should be prose and not contain bullet points.
Include summary of stay including, if applicable, key issues, interventions, procedures, and treatments.
Include summary of condition at discharge.
Include recommendations for follow-up plans and ongoing treatment.
Write the text in the style of a discharge letter using medical terminology. Proceed chronologically, write factually, objectively and concretely, formally, professionally, politely, respectfully. Avoid generalizations, assumptions, verbose and cumbersome formulations, and redundancy. Do not invent or presume anything. Generally, formulate in the imperfect tense, reported speech from individuals (e.g., from patients) in subjunctive I, and medical assessments and diagnoses in the present tense.
Minimize hallucinations. Do not generate recommendations on your own or add anything. Write nothing about topics for which there is no information basis from the EHR.
Don't include all private information, such as ID and date of birth. Use ___ to represent names of patients and medical professionals.

[Your Hospital's Letterhead]

March 20, 2024

Patient's Name: ___  
Age: 65  
Gender: Female  
Admission Date: March 10, 2024  
Discharge Date: [To be filled upon eventual discharge]

Dear ___,

I am writing to provide a summary of your recent hospital stay from March 10 through March 20, 2024, at ___. You were admitted to our facility following a fall and subsequent loss of consciousness. Despite our expectation for a discharge on March 20, 2024, your condition necessitates further care, and you will not be discharged on the initially expected date.

Upon your admission on March 10, 2024, you presented with a decreased level of consciousness and a Glasgow Coma Scale score documented at 11, alongside noted slurring of speech. Subsequent diagnostic evaluations, including a CT scan on March 11, 2024, confirmed the presence of a hemorrhagic stroke located in the right hemisphere of your brain. This finding led to the diagnosis of an unspecified intracerebral hemorrhage (ICD-10: I61.9), a critical condition that required immediate medical intervention.

On March 11, 2024, a series of laboratory tests were conducted. The complete blood count (CBC) indicated a slightly low hemoglobin level and an elevated white blood cell count. Additionally, coagulation profiling showed an elevated INR, suggesting a prolonged bleeding time. In response, medical management was promptly initiated, which included the administration of Mannitol at a dose of 0.25 g/kg every six hours to address cerebral edema, as well as antihypertensives administered in varying doses adjusted per your blood pressure levels.

During your stay, medical evaluations noted persistent neurological impairments, namely right-sided weakness and continued slurred speech. Ongoing assessments revealed no significant improvement in your neurological status, with the Glasgow Coma Scale remaining at 11. Additional symptoms included episodes of agitation and confusion. As such, safety measures were implemented to prevent further falls, and discussions with your family took place to address prognosis and the need for ongoing care.

At this juncture, your condition remains critical, necessitating continued inpatient care. As such, a discharge date is currently not feasible. I advise that your family remain engaged with our multidisciplinary team as care needs evolve and further plans for rehabilitation and follow-ups are made.

Should you or your loved ones have any questions or require clarification on the course of your care, please do not hesitate to reach out.

Wishing you strength and a steady recovery.

Respectfully,

Dr. ___
